Main activities to achieve the objectives of the intervention are to enhance legal and institutional frameworks, building on UNESCO's leverage to influence duty-bearers, including judges, legislature, parliamentarians, and law enforcement bodies. This is done through evidence based policy formulation and recommendations, technical expertise, capacity building and advocacy. At the same time media, journalists, artists, academia and civil society are enabled by UNESCO to take an active role in this work, by capacity building and multi-stakeholders platforms. Trainings differ for different context, but could include countering hate speech, conflict sensitive or gender sensitive reporting as well as elections covering. Activities also facilitate pluralism and participation in media, promote gender equality in both media production and content, and empower citizens with increased media and information literacy competencies. The support to the 2005 Convention supports governance and cultural policy making through capacity buidling of cultural policy makers, civil society organisations and other stakeholders. Also platforms for interaction between governments and civil society for monitoring the Convention and contributing to evidence based culture policy making. Freedom of expression is a guiding principle of the Convention and artistic freedom a monitoring pillar of the convention. Mechanisms for UNESCO to optimize its contribution globally, in targeted countries (16 for culture and more than 80 for media) and within the UN are so called flagship reports where international standards and norms, including UN Action Plans and Conventions, are implemented and followed up, used as reference and for accountability and standard setting. These include the "World Trends Report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development" and the 2005 Convention Global Report "Re:Shaping Cultural Policies". Another activity is to contribute to community media policies and to enhance Media Literacy. Global Standard setting, developing media indicators, is also part of UNESCO’s work. Awareness raising and networking is supported for instance by organising celebrations of international days such as World Press Freedom Day, International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists and World Day for Cultural Diversity for Dialogue and Development.

title.narrative: UNESCO Freedom of Expression, Communication and Culture 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Extrabudgetärt stöd till UNESCOs sektioner för Yttrandefrihet, kommunikation och kultur 2018-2021 utifrån UNESCO's Strategi 39 C/5 samt till Unesco Institute for Statistics.
FN's organisation för utbildning, vetenskap och kultur - UNESCO - har genom fyra projektförslag sökt stöd från Sida för sin verksamhet när det gäller främjande av yttrandefrihet globalt, regionalt och nationellt genom två av sina verksamhetsområden; Kommunikation & Information samt Kultur. Ansökningspaketet består av två Special Accounts, dvs multigivarfonder för icke-öronmärkt flexibelt stöd till UNESCO's kärnverksamhet inom Kommunikation & Information samt två projektstöd som stöd till verksamhetsområdena kultur och statistik. Förslagen inkluderar: - Programdokument för "The Special Account for Freedom of Expression and the Safety of Journalists" från UNESCO's Communication & Information Sector - Programdokument för "The Special Account for the International Progarmme for Development of Communication" från UNESCO's Communication & Information Sector - Projektförslag "Reshaping Cultural Policies for the promotion of Fundamental Freedoms and the Diversity of Cultural Expressions" från UNESCO's Culture Sector - Projektförslag "Global Monitoring of Communication & Information" från UNESCO's Institute for Statistics
Sida ger stöd till UNESCO's normativa och operativa arbete för yttrandefrihet med det övergripande målet att skapa förutsättningar globalt för fri och självständig media, fritt och självständigt kulturliv, mångfald samt säkerhet för journalister. Verksamheten är både global och landspecifik, där globala komponenter i huvudsak är normativt orienterade och komponenter på landnivå fokuserar på kapacitetsutveckling, policyutveckling och implementering samt skapar arenor för dialog mellan ansvarstagare och civilsamhället. Verksamheten bedrivs genom ett sampel mellan det globala och landspecifika arbetet och genom synergier mellan de två verksamhetsområdena Kommunikation & Information samt Kultur. I fokus för verksamhet på landnivå är länder som präglas av ett demokratisk underskott, inklusive inskränkningar inom yttrandefrihet och brist på oberoende media och kulturliv. Jämställdhet är ett fokusområde för insatsen.
När det gäller det normativa arbetet globalt för yttrandefrihet och medieutveckling bidrar Kommunikation & Information-programmet (CI) i huvudsak till områdena säkerhet för journalister, yttrandefrihet online och offline, media literacy samt jämställdhet inom media. På landnivå bidrar programmet till landspecifika yttrandefrihetsinsatser i Afrika, MENA och Latinamerika inom lagstiftnings- och påverkansarbete samt kapacitetsbyggande insatser inom ICT, media, jämställdhet och journalistik, vilket är ett viktigt bidrag till att stärka demokratisering och yttrandefrihet i dessa länder. Programmet bidrar även till UNESCO's arbete med att utveckla globala indiktorer för media och internet genom IPDC - International Programme for the Development of Communication och UNESCO Institute for Statistics - UIS. CI-programmet kommer att stödjas genom två så kallade Multi-Donor Special Accounts i linje med en programansats för Sidas samarbete med UNESCO samt genom ett projektstöd till UIS.
Kulturprogrammet (CLT) är starkt förankrat i 2005 års UNESCO konvention för kulturell mångfald som har yttrandefrihet och jämställdhet som grundläggande principer. Kapacitetsutveckling på landnivå (16 länder) fokuserar på förståelse av konventionen och metoder för datainsamlig och uppföljning av konventionen, vilket bl a inkluderar bevakning av yttrandefrihet/kommunikation. Det globala normativa arbetet fokuserar på att dokumentera och formulera policies, standards och regleringar inom området. CLT-programmet stöds genom ett projektstöd.
Total budget för UNESCO's verksamheter 2018-2019 är för CI 185 MSEK och för CLT Expected Result 7 133,5 MSEK. Då står Regular Programme + Voluntary contributions för respektive 30% av CI och 75% av CLT. Ett flertal givare bidrar till det extrabudgetära stödet, ca 129 MSEK för CI, varav Sida 88 MSEK respektive 33,6 MSEK för CTL, varav Sida 28 MSEK. Därutöver är de största givarna EU, Världsbanken, Norge, Finland, Nederländerna, Kamerun och Schweiz.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Extrabudgetary support to UNESCO's sections on Communication and Information, and Culture
UNESCO has applied to Sida for funding to carry out its "Freedom of Expression, Communication and Culture Programme 2018-2021". The intervention aims at contributing to fostering freedom of expression at a global, regional and local level through two of its sections; Communication & Information and Culture.
Sida supports UNESCO's normative and operational work for freedom of expression with the overall objective to contibute to global conditions for free and independent media and cultural life including diversity of cultural expressions as well as safety for journalists. The work is both global and country specific, where global components are mainly normatively oriented while components on a country level focus on capacity building, policy development and implementation as well as create foras for dialogue between duty bearers and civil society. The programme is conducted through interplay between the global and country specific work and through synergies between the two sections' respective work, Communication & Information and Culture. In focus for the country work are countries characterized with democratic deficit, including restrictions on freedom of expression and lack of an independent media and cultural life. Gender equality is of main focus for the contribution.
For the global normative work for freedom of expression and media development is the Communication & Information Programme (CI) contributing to the areas of saftey for journalists, freedom of expression on line and offline, media literacy as well as gender in media. At a country level, the programme contributes to country specific freedom of expression projects in Africa, MENA and Latin America within the areas of justice and advocacy work and for capacity building projects within ICT, media, gender equality and journalism, which is an important contribution for the strengthening of democratization and freedom of expression in these countries. The programme also contributes to UNESCO's IPDC - Intenational Programme for the Development of Communication's and UIS - UNESCO's Institute for Statistics' work with the development of global indicators for media and Internet.
The Culture Programme (CLT) is strongly anchored in the UNESCO Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions 2005 with freedom of expression and gender equality as guiding principles. Capacity development at a country level (in 16 countries) focuses on the understanding of the Convention and methods for data collection and follow-up of the Convention, which includes monitoring freedom of expression and communication. The global normative work focuses on documentation and formulation of cultural policies, standards and legislation.

This intervention supports UNESCO's work on freedom of expression and 2005 Convention on culture diversity through the Communication and Information (CI) sector and the Culture (CLT) sector during the period 2018-2021. The main objectives correspond to expected results in the UNESCO's Medium Term Strategy for 2014-2021 (37 C/4) and Programme and Budget for 2018-2021 (39 C/5). The main objectives of the contribution are: Support to Communication and Information Sector: Outcome/expected result 1: Targeted Member States enhance legal and institutional frameworks related to the protection and promotion of freedom of expression online/offline, right of access to information and safety of journalists, in accordance with international standards (and UN Plan of Action on the Safety of Journalists and the Issue of Impunity) and through integrating a gender sensitive approach. Outcome/expected result 2: Member States have benefited from enhanced media contributions to diversity, gender equality and youth empowerment in and through media; and societies are empowered through media and information literacy programmes and effective media response to emergency and disaster. Outcome/expected result 3: Media development is strengthened, and Member States have improved monitoring and reporting systems, and these results are reinforced by external grass roots projects supported by the International Programme for the Development of Communication (IPDC). Support to the Culture Sector: Outcome/Expected result: Governments and civil society organizations engage in evidence-based and participatory policy making and monitoring processes in accordance with the principles and objectives of the 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions. Support to UNESCO Institute for Statistics (UIS): This is considered by Sida a pilot, with the aim of strengthening UIS' role and a coordinated work between CI, IPDC and UIS to contribute to data collection and statistics for freedom of expression and SDG 16.
The above objectives correspond directly to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and contribute in particular to SDG 16:10 and its targets 16:10:1 and 16:10:2 and also SDG 4, 5, 9, 13. The support to the CI sector is channelled through two multi donor accounts, the Multidonor Programme for Freedom of expression and the Safety of Journalists and the Multidonor Special Account for the International Programme on Development Communication (IPDC). Key features of the programmes include support to the UN Action Plan for the Safety of Journalists and Issues of Impunity, The World Trends report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development, monitoring of SDG 16:10, Internet Universality Indicator Suite, to mention a few. Activities serve to promote the development, adoption and implementation of relevant policies and normative frameworks to strengthen the environment for freedom of expression and press freedom and to support sustainable and independent media institutions. Main activities to achieve the objectives of the intervention are to enhance legal and institutional frameworks, building on UNESCO's leverage to influence duty-bearers, including judges, legislature, parliamentarians, and law enforcement bodies. This is done through evidence based policy formulation and recommendations, technical expertise, capacity building and advocacy. At the same time media, journalists, artists, academia and civil society are enabled by UNESCO to take an active role in this work, by capacity building and multi-stakeholders platforms. Trainings differ for different context, but could include countering hate speech, conflict sensitive or gender sensitive reporting as well as elections covering. Activities also facilitate pluralism and participation in media, promote gender equality in both media production and content, and empower citizens with increased media and information literacy competencies. The support to the 2005 Convention supports governance and cultural policy making through capacity buidling of cultural policy makers, civil society organisations and other stakeholders. Also platforms for interaction between governments and civil society for monitoring the Convention and contributing to evidence based culture policy making. Freedom of expression is a guiding principle of the Convention and artistic freedom a monitoring pillar of the convention. Mechanisms for UNESCO to optimize its contribution globally, in targeted countries (16 for culture and more than 80 for media) and within the UN are so called flagship reports where international standards and norms, including UN Action Plans and Conventions, are implemented and followed up, used as reference and for accountability and standard setting. These include the "World Trends Report on Freedom of Expression and Media Development" and the 2005 Convention Global Report "Re:Shaping Cultural Policies". Another activity is to contribute to community media policies and to enhance Media Literacy. Global Standard setting, developing media indicators, is also part of UNESCO’s work. Awareness raising and networking is supported for instance by organising celebrations of international days such as World Press Freedom Day, International Day to End Impunity for Crimes against Journalists and World Day for Cultural Diversity for Dialogue and Development.

strategy.title: Human rights, democracy and the rule of law 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Mänskliga rättigheter, demokrati och rättsstatens principer 2018-2022

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Yttrandefrihet är en mänsklig rättighet och en av pelarna i en fungerande demokrati. Runt om i världen hotas medias frihet och enligt Freedom House har yttrandefriheten i världen minskat konsekvent och nu nått sin lägsta punkt på 13 år. Till och med i stora demokratier hotas journalister och auktoritära stater hittar nya vägar för att kontrollera media även utanför deras lands gränser. Internet och sociala medier har å ena sidan möjliggjort att journalister, informationsaktivister och vanliga individer kan nå ut med information snabbt, billigt och till en potentiellt mycket stor publik, å andra sidan har det också försett utländska och inhemska aktörer med en extremt användbar och billig plattform för spridandet av hat eller desinformation. I ett flertal länder behöver journalister och andra informationsaktivister riktat, kontinuerligt stöd för att motstå vissa myndigheters eller andra aktörers taktik för att censurera, snedvrida och blockera information.
Internews har inkommit med ett förslag till Sida om finansiering av deras Closed States Programme Strategi (2020-2024) med 75 MSEK. Close States Programme syftar till att stärka yttrandefriheten och tillgången till oberoende och ocensurerad information i flera av världens mest ofria länder. Detta kommer att ske genom att lokala journalister och informationsaktivister får kompetensutbildning och tillgång till ny teknik för att på ett säkert sätt upprätthålla produktionen och spridningen av oberoende, ocensurerad information och göra den tillgänglig genom nya och/eller traditionella medie- och kommunikationskanaler. Den övergripande målsättningen för programmet är att tillgången på högkvalitativ och oberoende information kommer att öka i dessa länder och att denna information kommer att nå 12 miljoner människor, samt att kapaciteten och hållbarheten hos de 50 lokala mediaaktörer kommer att stärkas genom skräddarsydda kapacitetsutbildningar vad det gäller produktion av högkvalitativ journalistik, organisatorisk färdighet och ekonomisk hållbarhet.
Sida avser att hantera och följa upp insatsens utveckling och resultat på programnivå. Dock kommer Sidas stöd att öronmärkas för särskilda poster i enlighet med bilagd budget. Skälet till detta är att andra givares projektstöd inom programmet inte svarar upp mot Sidas krav på kvalitetssäkring, varken avseende årlig revision eller tröskelvärden på revision av tredje part. Därav ser Sida sig nödgade att avtalsmässigt och revisionsmässigt hantera stödet som ett projektstöd med en öronmärkt Sida budget som årligen revideras. De andra stora givarna är Europeiska Kommissionen, Nederländerna, Frankrike och USA och dessa stödjer landspecifika projekt inom programmet.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Freedom of Expression is a Human Right and one of the pillars of Democracy. Freedom of Media across the globe is seriously declining. Monitoring undertaken by Freedom House shows media freedom has dropped to its lowest point in 13 years. Unprecedented threats to journalists and media outlets in major democracies and new moves by authoritarian states to control the media, including beyond their borders, are taking place. Social media on the one hand have allow ordinary people, civic groups, and journalists to reach a vast audience at little or no cost, but on the other hand it have also provided an extremely useful and inexpensive platform for malign influence operations by foreign and domestic actors alike. What was once a liberating technology has now also become a conduit for surveillance and electoral manipulation. In many countries journalists and other information activists need targeted, sustained support to withstand authorities’ tactics to censor, distort and block information.
Internews has submitted a proposal to Sida for funding of their Closed State Programme (CSP) Strategy (2020-2024) with 75,5 MSEK. The proposed programme aims to reach the most vulnerable populations in repressive authoritarian states and conflict affected areas of the globe with independent and uncensored information. This will be done by providing local journalists and other information activists with cutting edge skills and technologies to safely and securely sustain the production and dissemination of independent, uncensored information and make it available to their audiences through new or traditional media and communication channels.
Sida will monitor the development and the results of the support at programme level. Sida's support will, however, be earmarked for in accordance with the attached budget. The reason for this is that other donors' project support within the programme does not meet Sida's requirements for quality assurance, neither regarding annual audits nor thresholds for third party audits. As a result, Sida deems it necessary to manage the support in terms of contractual and audit terms as a project support with an earmarked Sida budget that is revised annually. The other major donors are the European Commission, the Netherlands, France and the United States and these support country-specific projects within the programme.

The Theory of Change for the Closed States Programme:
The Closed States Programme aims to reach 12 million people with information produced, by the 50 information providers strengthened through the programme.

description.narrative: Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Mana (SAICM) är en internationell, icke bindande, överenskommelse. Syftet är att bidra till att kemikalier hanteras på ett säkert sätt . Målet är att 2020 ska kemikalier hanteras på ett sätt så att hälsa och miljö inte skadas. Quick Start Program (QSP) är ett program för att u-länder ska komma igång med kemikaliearbetet.www.saicm.org

The Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management, Quick Start Programme. SAICM is a policy framework to promote chemical safety around the world. Its overall objective the achievement of the sound management of chemicals throughout their life cycle so that, by 2020, chemicals are produced and used in ways that minimize significant adverse impacts on human health and the environment. Quick Start Program is a fund to kickstart developing countries.

"SAICM Quick Start Programme" var en tidsbegränsad förvaltningsfond (Trust Fund) som startades 2006 och avslutades i december 2019 och som administrerades av FN:s miljöprogram UNEP. Målet med programmet var att "stödja initial kapacitetsuppbyggnad för en hållbar kemikaliehantering och genomförandeaktiviteter i utvecklingsländer, minst utvecklade länder, önationer och länder med övergångsekonomier". Medel tilldelade programmet användes för att finansiera projekt i länder som syftade mot att uppnå en förbättrad kemikalie- och avfallshantering i enlighet med den den globala kemikaliestrategin: "Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management (SAICM)". SAICM är ett internationellt policyramverk som antogs 2006 för hantering av kemikalier och avfall. Till skillnad från ett antal relaterade konventioner som behandlar enskilda kemikalier och avfallsfrågor tar SAICM alltså ett helhetsgrepp. SAICMs nuvarande mål går ut 2020 och en process är inledd för att ta fram en nya agenda för kemikalier och avfall: "SAICM Beyond 2020". Den processen är försenad på grund av Covid-pandemin. De internationella förberedelsemötena och kongresserna planeras att återupptas under andra halvåret 2021.

description.narrative: SAICM Quick Start Programme höll sin sista inbjudan till att söka medel från fonden 2015, varefter programmet sekretariat, baserat i Geneve, har förvaltat och följt upp de finansierade projekten tills dess att fonden formellt avslutades i december 2019. The Quick Start Programme Trust Fund har sedan starten 2006 beviljat medel till 184 projekt omfattande ca 38,5 MUSD i 108 länder varav 54 minst utvecklade länder eller små önationer. Den tematiska spännvidden på projekten har varit mycket bred, då SAICM till sin natur tar en bred ansats på kemikaliehantering. I stort sett alla projekt har avslutats helt, några få är i olika stadier av avslutning. En utvärdering publicerades i september 2015 vilken konkluderade att många goda resultat föreligger, men att det ofta förekom förseningar i projekten, att sekretariatet var underbemannat och att gender inte behandlades i tillräcklig utsträckning. Målet var att alla projekt skulle avslutas före årsskiftet 2018 och fonden avslutades 31 december 2019.

description.narrative: Children affected by the conflict in opposition-held areas in Syria have access to quality education and protection and their psychosocial well-being is promoted through: 1. Quality basic education is provided to children and attendance to school is ensured. 2. Vulnerable children affected by the conflict in opposition-held areas receive appropriate Psychosocial support 3. Children and their families receive adequate support and school attendance barriers are lifted. 4. The local administration is involved and a management and monitoring system for the program is in place and running.
Students from first grade to tenth grade
The education and individual development of children most affected by the conflict in Syria is improved

Accountability in Tanzania Phase Two (AcT2) Programme is a five year £38m, innovative and exciting programme whose purpose is to increase the responsiveness and accountability of Government in Tanzania, through a strengthened civil society. AcT2 seeks to support civil society organisations (CSOs) to implement context-specific strategic interventions that will enable them to influence positive change in the attitudes and behaviour of citizens, civil society and government, making government as a whole more responsive and accountable. The second phase started in February 2018 and will end in December 2022. The programme funds mid-to-large sized Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) and is managed by KPMG Advisory Limited in Tanzania. The programme works with CSO partners supporting Tanzanian citizens to engage with and hold their government to account. This is crucial to fostering a well-functioning state that acts in the best interests of its people - in tackling corruption, efficient spending of public resources and delivering effective public services. The Tanzanian President has made anti-corruption his top priority. AcT2 partners seeks to deploy different tools and resources to equip citizens to challenge corruption rather than accept it. AcT2 programme underlines the need to bolster groups that can continue to champion pluralism, articulate the demands of citizens, and engage in constructive debate and negotiation with government. As an integrated and cohesive civil society offer, AcT2 enables DFID to deliver greater impact from our wider portfolio priorities in human development and sustainable growth teams and promoting democratic space. It will do this through focusing on governance blockages in these areas, with a focus on promoting accountability and social inclusion, especially focusing on gender, disability and youth/elderly groups. The programme has ambition to deploy different innovative approaches including policy research, advocacy, dialogue, experimentation, and brokering, and it will work with civil society, private sector actors, elected officials and faith-based groups. The four thematic priorities for the programme includes: • Civic Space (sector policy dialogues, media, voice, CS advocacy, human rights) • Social Inclusion (disability, women, girls and youth/elderly) • Anti-Corruption • Climate Change

reporting-org.narrative: Auschwitz Institute for the Prevention of Genocide and Mass Atrocities

title.narrative: Activity 05: Great Lakes Focal Points Meeting

description.narrative: The Great Lakes Region Focal Points Meeting involving National Committee (NC) members from both Anglophone and Francophone countries in the region was conducted through a series of activities that included: (I) A total of 6 zoom meetings focusing on IBV crosscutting themes; (ii) Research and production of 7 country-specific case studies; and (iii) Generation of regional strategies and recommendations (Francophone and Anglophone states) to facilitate collaboration among states, regional, and continental inter-governmental organizations. As part of adopting to the current programming challenges raised by COVID-19, the above events involved 29 Focal Persons selected from active members of the respective NC’s represented their respective countries.

title.narrative: COVID19 RESPONSE FOR THE UGANDAN NORTHERN TRANSPORT CORRIDOR

description.narrative: Amref Health Africa Uganda and Healthy Entrepreneurs-HE partner to support districts, health workers and communities along the Northern Transport Corridor to respond effectively to the virus. We aim to mobilize and build the capacity of a network of Village Health Teams (VHTs) and health workers along the northern transport corridor (Luwero, Nakasongola, Kiryandongo and Amuru to Elegu border) to scale up the efforts for increased awareness, prevention, control and management of COVID-19 and to support continuity of SRH and other related medical services. The intervention is proposed for a period of six months, working with ~4000 VHTs and ~132 health workers (HWs) from selected ~33 health facilities. The activities include: A) capacity building of VHTs for community mobilization, B) deployment of a dedicated and free surveillance support line for health workers (HWs), C) development and distribution of contextualized communication materials for Districts, VHTs, HWs and the general public, and dissemination of MOH continuity of essential services guidelines, D) procurement and distribution of PPEs for HWs and E) support coordination and technical support for districts.

reporting-org.narrative: African Center for Global Health and Social Transformation

title.narrative: Health Systems Advocacy Partnership: ACHEST activities in Zambia

description.narrative: ACHEST HSAP activities in Zambia from January to December 2017 Quarter 1 January - March Participated in a planning meeting for the launch of the joint HSAP Zambia Started the process of registering ACHEST as an organisation Held a planning meetings for a dissemination meeting of the baseline findings in the districts the study was conducted in. Quarter 2 April - June ACHEST trained and mentored Amref in Community Health Worker research activities. ACHEST took part in collecting and analysing the data in the Zambian context ACHEST Zambia reached out to the Zambia Centre for Applied Health Research and Development (ZCAHRD) country director, Dr Biemba and scheduled a meeting to discuss attendance of this very important capacity building workshop scheduled for August, 2017 in Kampala, Uganda hosted by ACHEST Uganda. Margarate from ACHEST met with Dr Biemba and information about the partnership, ACHEST Zambia and the capacity building workshop was shared. A representative from this organization who would attend the meeting was also suggested. A member of ACHEST attended the dissemination meeting based on community health worker research at Amref in Kenya Quarter 3 July - September ACHEST trained and mentored MeTA in their research on SRH commodities in August/September Held meeting with the Minister of Health on HR transfers- HRH distribution in general. This was a very fruitful meeting as information on the partnership was disseminated and possibilities for future collaborations discussed Held a meeting with Member of Parliament in September after interview regarding ACHEST work. This activity created a platform for ACHEST to lobby at parliamentary level for SRHR issues as the meeting established a relationship with some of the parliamentarians Quarter 4 October - December The highlight during this quarter was CSO training in lobby and advocacy. Held two CSO and Media Lobbying and Advocacy training workshops in In Kitwe at the Greek Olive and Lusaka at Mika Lodge. In November and December respectively. This activity was also an opportunity for ACHEST members to also gain more skills in advocacy and lobbying for evidence based policies, by holding discussions with these CSOs and media, and also share some information about research. 18 CSOs were trained with a total of 41 representatives 21 males and 20 females. ACHEST Zambia attended a meeting with Young Women in Action in order to get more acquainted with their activities. During the January-March 2018 period , ACHEST trained 15 CSOs in February 2018. The training was aimed at building capacity in research skills around Sexual and Reproductive Health among the CSOs and HSA partners. Of the 15 people trained, 6 were female. The HSA partnership held a meeting with the members of parliament. The main purpose of the meeting was to introduce the HSA partnership including ACHEST and advocate for HRH and availability and access to SRH commodities. In the meeting it was agreed that the members of parliament would join in advocating for SRHR

ACHEST activities will fall into three areas:- i) Creating evidence on which to base advocacy strategies through research ii) Developing the capacities of relevant stakeholders in lobby and advocacy ii) Lobby and advocacy for adequate HRH and financing and good governace. ACHEST Iception phase activities in Zambia in 2016 will focus on: 1.Establishing project management systems including governance, financial management, operations and communication 2.Engaging and introducing the project to stakeholders in Zambia through an inception workshop and face-to face meetings 3.Baseline and evidence gathering 4. Situation analysis on HRH in Zambia with special attention to the needs of SRH .5. Situation analysis for financing and governance 6. Mapping of SRHR CSOs active in Zambia. 7 Analysis of policy environment and data on status of performance of existing policies and initiatives. 8.Identification of gaps and opportunities for interventions in SRH and HRH

MCC and the Government of El Salvador entered into force a compact agreement on September 9, 2015, to invest up to $277 million in regulatory reforms, education, and logistical infrastructure, with the goal of promoting economic growth and private investment in the country.
Over five years, the project trained over 4,500 teachers, school directors, and education specialists; constructed 32 schools; and launched El Salvador?s first two Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs).
Compact implementation was heavily impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, however, in a testament to El Salvador?s commitment to country ownership, the government has agreed to continue the funding and implementation of the compact?s projects.

condition.narrative: Each of the Officers has been selected and engaged by MCA-El Salvador and approved by MCC

MCA-El Salvador has delivered to MCC the following in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: (ii) copies of any reports from any technical (including environmental) auditors engaged by MCA-El Salvador for any Activity delivered since the previous Disbursement Request.

MCA-El Salvador has delivered to MCC the following in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: (iii) a certificate of MCA-El Salvador, dated as of the date of such Disbursement Request, substantially in the form provided by MCC (the ?MCA Disbursement Certificate?).

MCA-El Salvador has delivered to MCC the following in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: (v) a certificate of the Fiscal Agent, substantially in the form provided by MCC (the ?Fiscal Agent Disbursement Certificate?).

MCA-El Salvador has delivered to MCC the following in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: (i) a completed Disbursement Request, together with the Periodic Reports covering the related Disbursement Period.

MCA-El Salvador has delivered to MCC the following in form and substance satisfactory to MCC: (iv) a certificate of the Procurement Agent, substantially in the form provided by MCC (the ?Procurement Agent Disbursement Certificate?).
MCA-El Salvador has developed a complete Implementation Plan.
MCA-El Salvador has developed the Fiscal Accountability Plan (or an interim version), and the plan has been approved by MCC.
MCA-El Salvador has developed the M&E Plan, and the plan has been approved by the Board and MCC.
MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (i) all applicable conditions precedent in Annex 2 have been duly satisfied, deferred or waived as provided in this Agreement.
MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (iii) the activities to be funded with such Disbursement will not violate any applicable law or regulation.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (iv) the Implementation Plan Documents and Fiscal Accountability Plan are current and updated and are in form and substance satisfactory to MCC, and there has been progress satisfactory to MCC on the components of the Implementation Plan for any relevant Projects or Activities related to such Disbursement.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (ix) the Government has satisfied all of its payment obligations, including any insurance, indemnification, tax payments or other obligations, and contributed all resources required from it, under the Compact, this Agreement and any other Supplemental Agreement.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (vi) all Government entities involved in the implementation of the Program, including the Implementing Entities, are coordinating successfully with MCA-El Salvador and dedicating the necessary staff and other resources to ensure successful implementation of the Program;

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (viii) any Taxes paid with MCC Funding through the date ninety (90) days prior to the start of the applicable Disbursement Period have been reimbursed by the Government in full in accordance with Section 2.8(c) of the Compact;

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (x) MCC does not have grounds for concluding that any matter certified to it in the related MCA Disbursement Certificate, Procurement Agent Disbursement Certificate or Fiscal Agent Disbursement Certificate is not as certified.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (xi) no act, omission, condition, or event has occurred that would be the basis for MCC to suspend or terminate, in whole or in part, the Compact or MCC Funding in accordance with Section 5.1 of the Compact.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that: (xiv) The Government has complied in all material respects with its obligations set forth in Section 2.13 with respect to the making of its contributions in accordance with the projected timeline set forth in Annex 3.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that:(ii) no material default or breach of any covenant, obligation or responsibility by the Government, MCA-El Salvador or any Government entity has occurred and is continuing under the Compact, this Agreement or any other Supplemental Agreement.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that:(v) there has been progress satisfactory to MCC on the M&E Plan and Social and Gender Integration Plan for the Program, relevant Project or Activity and substantial compliance with the requirements of the M&E Plan and Social and Gender Integration Plan (including the targets set forth therein and any applicable reporting requirements set forth therein for the relevant Disbursement Period).

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that:(vii) there has been no material negative finding in any financial audit report delivered in accordance with the Compact and Audit Plan, for the prior two quarters (or such other period as the Audit Plan may require);

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that:(xii) each of the Officers remains engaged, or if a position is vacant, MCA-El Salvador is actively engaged, to MCC?s satisfaction, in recruiting a replacement.

MCC has determined in its sole discretion that:(xiii) MCA-El Salvador has complied in all material respects with its obligations set forth in Section 2.1(d) with respect to the establishment of a BCS and its obligations set forth in Section 2.3 with respect to the establishment of an M&E Plan.

Prior to any Disbursement of Program Funding on or after the commencement of year five (5) of the Compact Term, the Government must have submitted to MCC an initial draft Compact Closure Plan in accordance with the MCC Program Closure Guidelines.

Prior to the initial Disbursement of Program Funding for payment under a particular works or construction contract for a given Project or Activity, as determined by MCC, MCA-El Salvador must have submitted to MCC evidence in form and substance satisfactory to MCC that: (B) MCA-El Salvador or the appropriate Government entity is implementing the requirements of each ESMS, ESIA, ESMP, Health and Safety Management Plan (?HSMP?) or RAP, as appropriate, in all material respects and consistent with the MCC Environmental Guidelines (including the IFC Performance Standards that are incorporated by reference therein).

Prior to the initial Disbursement of Program Funding for payment under a particular works or construction contract for a given Project or Activity, as determined by MCC, MCA-El Salvador must have submitted to MCC evidence in form and substance satisfactory to MCC that:(A) MCA-El Salvador has developed a Project-specific ESMS; an Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (?ESIA?); an Environmental and Social Management Plan (?ESMP?); and/or a Resettlement Action Plan (?RAP?), and/or the relevant government entity has enacted any necessary national legal provisions necessary for timely implementation of property takings required by such RAP, each of which must be in form and substance satisfactory to MCC in accordance with the MCC Environmental Guidelines and IFC Performance Standards.

Prior to the initial Disbursment of Program Funding, MCA-El Salvador will have developed and approved a comprehensive Compact-wide Environment and Social Management System (?ESMS?). That ESMS will provide a framework and principles that will guide the development of Project specific ESMS.

Prior to the second Disbursement of Program Funding, MCA-El Salvador will have developed and approved a comprehensive Social and Gender Integration Plan, in form and substance satisfactory to MCC. The Social and Gender Integration Plan will include an assessment and define which entities associated with the Compact will be required to establish a gender unit, appoint a gender focal point, and/or develop a gender policy, indicating the required periods for its development and implementation in agreement with each entity?s authority.
The Compact has entered into force as provided in Article 7 of the Compact.

title.narrative: Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty

description.narrative: Our prior project with the Dutch Government, “Subsistence to Self-Reliance – Bringing the Power of Markets to Africa’s Lowest-Income Farmers” underscored our shared passion for inclusive economic development and showcased the key milestones that we can accomplish together. Core operating support from DGIS facilitated the strategic expansion of One Acre Fund’s ‘impact ecosystem.’ Within two years, we doubled the scale of our farmer network, launched operations in two new country programs (Malawi and Uganda), and rolled out impactful new products like tree planting kits and clean cookstoves at country-wide scale. Simultaneously, we refined our innovative systems-change platform, leveraging our core organizational competencies to improve large-scale public and private actors’ service to smallholders. This success has now placed One Acre Fund in a position where we can realistically envision moving the needle on hunger and poverty across the entire African continent. Our current project with DGIS, “Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty,” aims to capture this powerful opportunity. The project involves a smartly structured two-part investment spanning September 15, 2018 – December 31, 2022: First, DGIS is once again providing critical support to the varied, evolving platforms within our organization that lay the foundation for our growth and impact. Core operating support from DGIS will enhance and extend One Acre Fund’s proven model by funding key strategic priorities across our M&E, R&D, and new country expansion units. Secondly, DGIS is also providing working capital to revolutionize One Acre Fund’s growth trajectory. This injection to our ‘permanent fund’ will completely fund our projected expansion of 245,000+ new farm families in 2019, bringing us past the 1 millionth farmer milestone. Crucially, farmers’ loan repayments will replenish our permanent fund each year, allowing us to re-extend this contribution to provide input loans to an estimated 245,000 farm families (including over 980,000 children) annually. This project will anchor One Acre Fund’s expansion to directly serve 1.85 million farm families annually by year-end 2022. Simultaneously, it will help us reach an additional 3.5 million farmers via systems-change partnerships that are expressly designed to transform entire agricultural ecosystems. Together, the reach of these efforts will generate transformative change for rural communities across rural Africa.

[Note: This grant does not fund our Burundi operations.] Burundi 2021 Q2 Country Update: Our Burundi program continues to perform well, moving on from past government suspensions, potentially contentious presidential elections, and the effects of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Program growth is relatively conservative due to our strategy of pausing outward expansion (i.e., opening new districts or sites) in response to regulatory and election-related uncertainty, instead opting to increase enrollment in current sites.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: Farm families participating in One Acre Fund's core program.

comment.narrative: We are pleased to report that strong farmer demand for our services enabled us to achieve an above-target scale growth to serve 105,000 farm families (encompassing approximately 556,500 beneficiaries, including 283,500 children). This growth has been fueled by strong farmer demand for our services, coupled with the reality that access to high-quality inputs is quite limited in Burundi. To serve this greater number of farmers, our Burundi program also successfully grew to 753 total field staff; the vast majority of these staff are from the communities we serve, and many are farmers themselves.

We reached 110,000 farm families in 2020, growing 5% year-on-year. This relatively conservative expansion is due to our strategy of pausing outward expansion (i.e., opening new districts or sites) due to regulatory and election-related uncertainty, as well as our desire to improve margins and impact before resuming robust growth.

Year-on-year growth of 15% in Burundi was driven by robust farmer demand for our program, and facilitated by our scaling of digital services, including mobile money repayment options, mobile phone enrollment, and additional services (e.g., e-banking and real-time information sharing). These innovations will not only have lasting improvements to our impact and efficiency, but will also support financial and digital inclusion for Burundi’s rural farmers.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: The profit boost achieved by farming with One Acre Fund.

comment.narrative: In 2019, we attained an average impact of $34 per farm family - well below our historical impact trajectory in the country. We attribute this shortfall to extensive, consecutive regulatory challenges. For instance, our November 2018 operational suspension (in the 2019A season) limited the products we were able to offer (preventing our distribution of solar lights or trees) and forced a streamlined training schedule that lowered farmer compliance. Similarly, in the 2019B season, many farmers missed the ideal window for planting due to delays among Burundi’s authorized fertilizer importers. In spite of these challenges, One Acre Fund remained a strong investment for Burundi’s farm families last year, boosting income from supported activities by nearly 27%.

We exceeded our internal core program dollar impact target, a substantial accomplishment in the context of Burundi’s deep poverty and 2020’s host of external challenges. Key factors in this success include: 1) favorable weather that led to above-average bean harvests from the 20B season; 2) work by our government relations, procurement, and logistics teams to ensure farmers received inputs on time and in the right quantities; and 3) adaptation of our training program to ensure delivery of a full suite of field trainings that comply with social distancing protocols (e.g., limiting training group size).

We project that clients will boost their incomes by $75, a meaningful sum in Burundi's communities facing extreme levels of poverty. Key factors include favorable weather, program adaptations to enable safe operation, successful/on-time distribution of inputs, and the distribution of impactful agricultural and quality-of-life products (e.g., trees, solar lights, cookstoves, and cell phones).

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: One Acre Fund's key cost-effectiveness measure.

comment.narrative: Since the obligatory removal of our service fees in 2018 by the Burundi government, we have been pursuing operational efficiencies and smart cost-cutting for non-core activities (e.g., R&D) to ensure long-term financial sustainability in the country. We are drawing on our valuable cost-cutting experience in Rwanda, whose smallholder sector closely resembles Burundi’s, and where in 2016, this government also prohibited our collection of service fees. In 2017, program streamlining cut 20% from Rwanda’s net deficit, helping to generate $4.70 in farmer impact per donor dollar. We believe that our Burundi program is well-positioned to achieve similar outcomes over time.

We achieved 100% loan repayment in the 2020B season (2020 reporting), once again demonstrating extraordinary farmer demand for and satisfaction with our Burundi program. Loan repayment is projected to cover 72% of total program costs in Burundi, slightly better than our 2019 results. Factors affecting this result include lower revenues due to narrow margins, higher costs due to unbudgeted COVID-19 spending (including health trainings to clients and soap distribution to clients and their neighbors), and higher transport costs related to fertilizer supply chain challenges.

We are on track to exceed our 2021 SROI targets. To reduce costs, we are continuing to improve field officer efficiency and performance, driving up the number of farmers each officer serves to reach a ratio of 340 farmers served per Field Officer (vs 292 in 2020). Additionally, our shift from cash-based to mobile phone-based repayment is generating significant time and cost savings, while improving convenience and transparency for clients. Together with on-track impact, we are projecting a 2021 SROI of 3.1. We will also switch from cash-based to mobile phone-based repayment to generate significant time and cost savings, while improving convenience and transparency for clients.

title.narrative: Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty

description.narrative: Kenya Q2 2021 Country Update: One Acre Fund farmers are completing a successful planting season despite ongoing COVID-19 related challenges, including new waves of infections in rural Kenya and subsequent government-mandated nightly curfews in the country’s Western region where we primarily operate. Following successful input delivery and planting earlier this year (alongside related trainings), our Kenyan core program clients received harvest and post-harvest training while they reaped their crops. Additionally, our team is continuing to roll out our new multi-channel program; this re-envisioned program model, dubbed “Project Ustawi” (the Swahili word for wellbeing), will connect our core program, network of Duka retail shops, and a new digital platform to offer more flexible services and improve our overall customer experience.

Our prior project with the Dutch Government, “Subsistence to Self-Reliance – Bringing the Power of Markets to Africa’s Lowest-Income Farmers” underscored our shared passion for inclusive economic development and showcased the key milestones that we can accomplish together. Core operating support from DGIS facilitated the strategic expansion of One Acre Fund’s ‘impact ecosystem.’ Within two years, we doubled the scale of our farmer network, launched operations in two new country programs (Malawi and Uganda), and rolled out impactful new products like tree planting kits and clean cookstoves at country-wide scale. Simultaneously, we refined our innovative systems-change platform, leveraging our core organizational competencies to improve large-scale public and private actors’ service to smallholders. This success has now placed One Acre Fund in a position where we can realistically envision moving the needle on hunger and poverty across the entire African continent. Our current project with DGIS, “Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty,” aims to capture this powerful opportunity. The project involves a smartly structured two-part investment spanning September 15, 2018 – December 31, 2022: First, DGIS is once again providing critical support to the varied, evolving platforms within our organization that lay the foundation for our growth and impact. Core operating support from DGIS will enhance and extend One Acre Fund’s proven model by funding key strategic priorities across our M&E, R&D, and new country expansion units. Secondly, DGIS is also providing working capital to revolutionize One Acre Fund’s growth trajectory. This injection to our ‘permanent fund’ will completely fund our projected expansion of 245,000+ new farm families in 2019, bringing us past the 1 millionth farmer milestone. Crucially, farmers’ loan repayments will replenish our permanent fund each year, allowing us to re-extend this contribution to provide input loans to an estimated 245,000 farm families (including over 980,000 children) annually. This project will anchor One Acre Fund’s expansion to directly serve 1.85 million farm families annually by year-end 2022. Simultaneously, it will help us reach an additional 3.5 million farmers via systems-change partnerships that are expressly designed to transform entire agricultural ecosystems. Together, the reach of these efforts will generate transformative change for rural communities across rural Africa.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: One Acre Fund's key cost-effectiveness measure.

comment.narrative: In 2019, our Kenya program attained an social return on investment (SROI) of 3.8 falling below our 2019 core program target of 4.8. Our SROI was affected by various challenges which include: 1) Constrained rainfall (rain started, farmers planted, and then rain stopped for a full month when crops were most vulnerable), 2) The aforementioned impact shortfall - which was as a result of material expansion into newer program areas (where One Acre Fund has less experience), and 3) Below target loan repayment which resulted in a shortfall of our sustainability target allowing for only 79% of our field costs being covered by farmer loan repayments, compared to our deliberately ambitious target of 88%.

SROI in 2020 was 4.7 despite of the unprecedented COVID-19 challenges this season. We recorded decreased revenues due to lower loan repayment; the Kenya program ended the 2020 season with 92.2% repayment, below our target and three-year average of 98%, yet largely in line with COVID-19 updated projections. We attribute the below-target repayment rate to farmer cash constraints caused by the ongoing pandemic, coupled with flooding and locust infestation in some parts of the country. We achieved sustainability of 85.3%, meaning that 85.3% of total costs for Kenya were covered by field revenues collected here.

We conservatively project to achieve a 2021 SROI of 2.7. While below our historical average due to the extraordinary operating environment, this result nonetheless would mean that every donor dollar generates $2.70 in new farm profits during a challenging operating year. Driven by economies of scale and evidence-based innovation, the Kenya program remains among the most cost-effective core programs, with farmers expected to cover 81% of core program expenses through loan repayment this year. We conservatively forecast to end the season with 90% loan repayment; while below our historical repayment rate of 97%, we consider it a positive outcome given the severe obstacles and financial strain the pandemic created for farmers. To mitigate against those obstacles and maximize loan repayment during this difficult year, we are extending our final repayment deadline by three weeks and investing more resources toward Field team support so that we can offer more customer service and follow-up.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: Farm families participating in One Acre Fund's core program.

comment.narrative: In 2019, we delivered our core program to 408,500 farm families. We plan to serve approximately 507,000 farm families - putting us on an exciting trajectory to achieve countrywide scale in one of Africa's most important agricultural markets.

Our Kenya program grew by 11% in 2020, reaching 451,700 farm families. Expansion was below historical growth due to impact challenges dating back to the last two seasons in which a perfect storm of ill-timed rainfall, crop damage from the invasive pest fall armyworm, and record-low maize prices reduced profits for farmers; these challenges understandably made farmers reluctant to commit to agricultural loans in 2020.

We saw strong enrollment of 533,000 clients program-wide in the 2021 long rains season, well above our target of 491,400. We attribute this growth to three main factors: (1) digitization, which offers farmers an expanded range of interactive services accessible via mobile phones; (2) 2020 debt relief scheme, in which we offered a 5% COVID-19 related discount for farmers who re-enrolled in 2021 following the successful implementation of debt relief initiatives last season (e.g., repayment extensions); and (3) pre-season qualification extension in February, which allowed farmers more time to meet qualifying re-payment requirements, in turn enabling some last-minute enrollment.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: The profit boost achieved with One Acre Fund.

comment.narrative: Our Kenya program experienced a second year of challenging impact in 2019, primarily due to adverse weather. Poorly timed rains meant that maize yields were lower than expected. Still, One Acre Fund remained a good investment for the average farmer – we estimate that Kenyan farmers achieved 43% higher incomes than their non-enrolled neighbors on activities we support. To preserve and deepen our impact moving forward, we are focused on improving farmer resilience through increased crop and income diversification (e.g., agroforestry, livestock, and other cash crops). We are running a number of distinct crop diversity trials in Central region, where farmers are already accustomed to growing a range of crops beyond maize and where we see strong potential for added impact. We are also working to optimize our input delivery schedule to better meet the needs of farmers in the northern part of Central region, where the rainy season is timed differently than our other program areas in Kenya.

We achieved per-farmer impact of $71 through our core program, below our internal targets. Primary drivers included COVID-related supply and training disruptions, flooding in some areas of Western Kenya, and crop pests. These external challenges reaffirm our commitment to bolstering farmer resilience through increased crop and income diversification, and meeting the needs of a broader range of clients through our Duka agrodealer shops.

We project that clients who farm with One Acre Fund in 2021 will see an income boost of $59 from activities we support. While M&E and harvest assessments are ongoing, these projections remain a conservative estimate. Final impact figures will be available in Q4. This below-target projection is driven by the effects of the pandemic, coupled with unfavorable weather. COVID-19 caused both supply chain and program disruptions, leading to delays in the delivery of products and limited in-person engagement. These challenges were compounded by an extended dry period across several areas of our operation, raising concerns about yields. Despite this, our program is delivering a significant boost yield for clients relative to non-client neighbors, a testament to One Acre Fund's ability to make farming more productive during another difficult year. poultry and additional crops), optimized agronomy (e.g. boosting adoption of agricultural lime), and commercialization initiatives (e.g. ongoing buyback trials with macadamia, chia, and avocado). We project an impact of $79 this year.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: Farm families reached through systems-change unit

comment.narrative: Though Kenya is one of our mature country programs, our systems-change work in the country remains at a much earlier stage than One Acre Fund's other country contexts (e.g., Rwanda). As mentioned in our previous reports, we are continuing to lay the groundwork for promising potential partnerships focused on rural retail and solar inputs. For example, to address farmers' demand for high-quality products year-round, we launched our rural retail trial in late 2019. In August 2019, we incorporated poultry sales into this trial, selling 122 chickens to 22 farmers in the first week of this intervention. We will look to scale these up in subsequent years if M&E demonstrates a strong impact and business case. Since the launch of this trial, we have sold 1,523 Rainbow Rooster chickens to over 100 farmers via 4 dukas.

We served 64,500 farmers in 2020 through our "Duka" agrodealer shops and partnerships. We achieved this by: 1) Ensuring distribution of an improved breed of chicken for sale at the Dukas (we sell 6-week-old Rainbow Rooster chickens, weighing an average of 450+ grams), 2) Improving SMS marketing for new and former Duka clients, 3) Exploring how best to utilize digital technology to boost the shops’ sales, 4) Providing accurate sales forecasting and inventory, and 5) Implementing a rolling delivery system to keep up with a growing volume of customers.

We are continuing to expand our rural retail program this year, which enables farmers to buy products year-round in rural retail shops, or "Dukas". Dukas are an innovative solution to increase quality input accessibility in Kenya and expand our reach to non-core farmer segments, especially those not interested in our standard group-liability loan program. To expand to reach more of this farmer segment, we plan to launch more than 50 new Dukas country-wide in 2021 (expanding from 23 to 75 total shops). While our scale growth is tracking slightly below target, this nonetheless reflects year-over-year growth of 297%.

title.narrative: Leading the Charge to Eradicate Rural Poverty

description.narrative: Our prior project with the Dutch Government, “Subsistence to Self-Reliance – Bringing the Power of Markets to Africa’s Lowest-Income Farmers” underscored our shared passion for inclusive economic development and showcased the key milestones that we can accomplish together. The project involves a smartly structured two-part investment spanning September 15, 2018 – December 31, 2022: First, DGIS is once again providing critical support to the varied, evolving platforms within our organization that lay the foundation for our growth and impact. Tanzania 2021 Q2 Country Update: We are continuing to scale our program in Tanzania despite the challenges brought on by COVID-19. Key to our ability to expand are our innovation trials launched in 2021. This year, our Program Innovations team in Tanzania is trialing a program in four districts dubbed “Shamba Darasa” (“farm classroom”). Farming plots under the program are primarily used to train field staff, but will also be used to test various planting recommendations to increase yields. Additionally, in a new trial aimed at boosting repayment rates, we are offering mobile phones to farmers as an add-on product in our package to improve access to digital services and mobile payment opportunities and boost digital literacy.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: One Acre Fund's key cost-effectiveness measure.

comment.narrative: Despite strong deficit-cutting, SROI was below target, primarily due to the aforementioned impact shortfall. We would also like to note that in the early years, Kenya and Rwanda also had SROIs below 1 (it takes time to build client trust and realize higher transactions and economies of scale to improve SROI).

We collected 94.7% of total loans disbursed country-wide in 2020, below our historical average of 97%. However, this is an improvement from our 2019 season’s result of 92% — a particularly positive outcome given the challenges faced by farmers during the pandemic. The main factors driving the year-over-year decrease in SROI include: lower revenues due to narrow margins, higher costs due to unbudgeted COVID-19 spending (including health trainings to clients and soap distribution to clients and their neighbors), and higher transport costs related to fertilizer supply chain challenges.

To strengthen SROI in 2021, we are focusing on improving the three “fundamentals” of efficiency: clients per Field Officer, transaction size per farmer, and farmer loan repayment. Some activities that are driving progress along these areas include phone distributions trials (to improve repayment), and equipping field officers with better tablet-based client management applications (to facilitate Field Officers to serve more clients; we drove the average from 180 to 242 this year).

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: Farm families reached through systems-change unit

comment.narrative: Given the strong relations we have with the government and the credibility of our growing core program, Tanzania has shown early potential for impact through our systems-change work. In 2019, we worked to strengthen partnerships in our ongoing rural retail shops project (as outlined in our previous updates) and advocacy on the removal of VAT (value-added tax) for impactful PICS crop storage bags.

In 2020, our systems change work in Tanzania consisted of two workflows: 1) a marketing incentive trial that uses a voucher subsidy to improve the adoption of hybrid maize seed and fertilizer in low adoption areas; and 2) the distribution of tree seedlings. We reached 28,000 farmers through the seed voucher program, and 4,000 through our agroforestry platform.

Our systems change work in Tanzania currently consists of three workflows: 1) a marketing incentive trial that uses a voucher subsidy to improve the adoption of hybrid maize seed and fertilizer in low adoption areas; 2) the distribution of tree seedlings; and 3) rural retail shops. The latter work stream will allow farmers in areas outside our core program to purchase high-quality farm inputs individually through local shops. This approach is attractive to farmers who want products year-round, who want products and training topics “à la carte,” or who are hesitant about group liability in our core program. Districts that had previously been unable to meet enrollment targets in Tanzania have adopted these initiatives and have seen early success in attracting farm families.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: The profit boost achieved by farming with One Acre Fund.

comment.narrative: Impact challenges in our growth countries (Uganda, Malawi, Tanzania, and Zambia) caused social return on investment (SROI) to dip below our targets for this cohort in 2019. Uncontrollable, external factors such as severe weather shocks, market price movements, currency fluctuations, and other shocks severely influenced our impact and SROI which led to lower harvests and farmer revenue, respectively. These factors decreased impact and farmer repayment while negatively affecting our revenue model via lower farmer repayment—i.e. decreasing our SROI. Our impact forecasts in Tanzania have meaningfully evolved since launching our latest partnership there in 2017. One Acre Fund Tanzania program is part of our ‘growth countries unit,’ a designation that refers to contexts where we are still refining our programming to achieve reliable impact and growth. Performance in such countries tends to be variable in line with changing realities on the ground; in Tanzania, two consecutive seasons (2018 and 2019) of challenging weather and low maize prices increased farmer risk aversion, affecting impact. Final impact figures will be shared in our 2020 Q1 update.

Our clients will achieve an average $50.9 incremental profit per farmer on supported activities, below our three-year average of $112. Despite impact levers such as the promotion of crop diversification, increased planting compliance, and stronger support for volunteer Group Leaders, flooding in the Southern Districts appear to have negatively affected our impact results.

We are tracking slightly below our impact target, at $45. Still, we believe that our work to improve farmer resilience through crop diversification and agroforestry will contribute to protecting food security during the pandemic. This year, we launched early-stage trials of new crops (e.g., biofortified beans) with the potential to further diversify farm families’ incomes, and expanded our tree portfolio to include avocado, pine, grevillea, and two soil-improving varieties.

description.narrative: Final figures for 2020, and projected results for 2021.

title.narrative: Farm families participating in One Acre Fund's core program.

comment.narrative: We concluded Tanzania's 2019 season serving 56,000 farm families country-wide slightly below our grant target of 60,000. We attribute this to two consecutive seasons (2018 and 2019) of challenging weather and low maize prices that have increased farmer risk aversion, affecting enrollment.

We finalized the 2020 season in Q3 of 2020, having served 61,400 farmers country-wide. This falls below our internal target for the year, and results from the program’s decision to deliberately slow growth and focus on program fundamentals following two seasons of impact and repayment challenges.
We are currently serving 67,820 clients, which represents 10% year-over-year growth from 2020.
